results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [Morwell veterans]
results.brief_description: Ten Victorian veterans from Morwell tell stories of their time of service, providing their unique perspectives on army life, wartime and coming home to Australia. Produced with the assistance of Morwell RSL and the students of Kurnai College, Morwell.

results.title: The Brothers Byrne
results.creator_credit: William Gough, Rex Tasker, Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Torn between the world of their childhood and the world where they must mow live and work, two flamboyant Newfoundlanders pay a nostalgic visit to the deserted outport where they were born. This is their story, and the story of so many others who, like them, became victims of the Newfoundland government’s controversial Resettlement Program. Credits include: Photography by Kent Nason.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Gough, Rex Tasker, Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.description: Torn between the world of their childhood and the world where they must mow live and work, two flamboyant Newfoundlanders pay a nostalgic visit to the deserted outport where they were born. results.title: One Week Later
results.creator_credit: Rachel Tunnard, Peter Snelling, Mandy Rathbone, Ferndown Upper School, PVA Medialab and First Light
results.brief_description: Told through the eyes of a younger pupil, who surveys the relationships his brother has with his peer group. As revelations and misunderstandings occur, due to the misuse of the ubiquitous mobile phone, the week’s events come to a climax on a Friday afternoon.

results.title: The Bones and muscles
results.creator_credit: Gail Prensky, JWM Productions and National Geographic Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Totally Gross Anatomy”.
Using 3D animation and x-ray footage, this video reveals the network of 206 bones and more than 600 muscles that combine to make up the human musculo-skeletal system. Students will investigate the composition of bones (the spongy inner layer, the compact outer layer and the types of marrow inside bones), and the importance of joints, tendons and muscles in ensuring that the skeleton not only gives the body a flexible framework, but also protects important internal organs. The video concludes with a series of assessment questions and answers designed to ensure that students understand basic concepts related to bones and muscles. Suitable for Mid-Upper Primary level students. Teacher’s guide included.

results.title: Win, lose or draw
results.creator_credit: Graeme MacLeod, Heather Williams, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
The staging of the Americas Cup in Fremantle had a huge impact on the redevelopment of Perth’s old seaport. Heritage buildings were restored, some lovingly, some superficially and new tourist and shopping precincts were created. This program explores the short and long-term effects of the development on the people of Fremantle, both rich and poor, businessmen and tenants and should give valuable lessons to others planning major redevelopment around a once-off major event such as the Americas Cup.

results.title: Tour of duty
results.creator_credit: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: While he saw it as his duty to defend his country against communism, it wasn’t until Paul Rayment went to Vietnam that he realised how lucky Australia really was. However, on his return, Rayment became estranged from his community and friends, and it took a while to rebuild those ties and his connection to the country he had earlier set out to defend.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Rayment, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: While he saw it as his duty to defend his country against communism, it wasn’t until Paul Rayment went to Vietnam that he realised how lucky Australia really was. However, on his return, Rayment became estranged from his community and friends, and it took a while to rebuild those ties and his connection to the country he had earlier set out to defend.

However, on his return, Rayment became estranged from his community and friends, and it took a while to rebuild those ties and his connection to the country he had earlier set out to defend.

results.title: Racconti: La Voce del popolo = The Voice of the people
results.brief_description:
Racconti: La Voce Del Popolo (The Voice of the People) is a powerful living memory and dedication to the lives of hard working Australian/Italians and celebrates the enormous contribution they have made to this country.
Through the Digital storytelling program at the Australian Centre for Moving Image (ACMI) the 10 storytellers were guided through the telling of a personal story using multimedia tools. The participants used their voice as narrative and combined the audio-visual resources of their personal archives (photographs, video footage, text, music and sound) and each storyteller has produced a 3 - 5 minute digital story that explores their experiences of migration and settlement.
Racconti: La Voce Del Popolo (the Voice of the People) was made possible through the partnership of the Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF) and the Australian Centre for the Moving Image (ACMI) with the support of the Victorian Multicultural Commission.

results.title: Didgeridoo in Deutschland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
Take an Aboriginal musician and an Australian composer … put them in the middle of Europe and what have you got? If the composer is George Dreyfus, the musician is Richard Walley, poet and exponent of the didgeridoo, and the European country is Germany, you get a fascinating look at two individuals whose people have been persecuted but whose vastly different cultures can come together in a totally satisfying work. Made with the assistance of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

results.title: One Man's Walk
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Mitchell, Interplay Theatre and First Light
results.brief_description: A boy walks down a street. We do not see his face. He is the event but we don’t know why. He tells us his likes and dislikes as he passes through the streets of his town. Finally we see his face and understand.

results.title: The Provincial connection
results.brief_description: Giancarlo came to Melbourne on board a ship in 1965 at the age of 15 and started work. By the age of 21 he had bought his first house. Giancarlo is now the president of the Ballarat Italian Association and celebrates “the positive contribution of Italians to Australia”. Created as part of the Racconti: La Voce del Popolo Digital Storytelling in association with The Italian Federation of Migrant Workers and their Families (FILEF).
